title: Build a Study Routine That Sticks
content:
Consistency beats intensity. A lightweight routine—same place, same time—removes decision fatigue and helps your brain slip into focus mode faster.

Start with a weekly template: plan deep work blocks, review sessions, and recovery time. Keep blocks short (25–50 minutes) with deliberate breaks to reset.

Use a simple system to capture tasks: one inbox, one planner, one calendar. If it isn’t captured, it won’t get done.

End each session with a two-minute shutdown: write what you finished, what’s blocked, and your first task for next time. Tomorrow-you will thank you.

title: A Friendly Introduction to Machine Learning
content:
Machine learning lets computers find patterns in data and make predictions. You feed examples in, the system learns a mapping, then evaluates on new inputs.

Supervised learning uses labeled examples (e.g., house price → number). Unsupervised learning finds structure without labels (e.g., grouping customers).

Start with the pipeline: define the problem, gather/clean data, choose a simple model, evaluate with a holdout set, and iterate. Simplicity first.

Beware overfitting: a model that memorizes the training set but fails on new data. Use cross-validation, regularization, and honest baselines.

title: Hit Straighter Golf Shots: A Practical Guide
content:
Straight shots start with a square clubface at impact. Use an alignment stick along your target line and match your toe line parallel to it.

Grip pressure should be firm-but-relaxed; death-gripping adds tension and manipulates the face. Focus on a smooth tempo—count 1-2 on the backswing, 3 on the downswing.

Practice a stock shot: small fade or draw. Consistency in one direction reduces big misses. Track start line and curve with a notebook or app.

Build a 30-ball routine: 10 warm-up, 10 technical (slow reps), 10 play-like (pre-shot routine). Finish by noting one feel that worked today.

title: Launch a Simple Portfolio Website in a Weekend
content:
A clean, fast portfolio showcases your work better than a flashy theme. Start with semantic HTML, mobile-first CSS, and minimal JavaScript.

Make the homepage a clear elevator pitch: who you are, what you do, and your top 3 projects with crisp screenshots and short case studies.

Add a lightweight blog for process notes. Write as you build—people love honest narratives about constraints, tradeoffs, and outcomes.

Ship early: deploy on a static host, set up a custom domain, and add analytics. Iterate weekly instead of waiting for perfect.

title: Time Management Essentials for Busy Students
content:
Plan the week before it starts. On Sundays, map deadlines and energy levels to pick the right task for the right moment.

Batch similar tasks: email, readings, problem sets. Context switching is expensive; batching lowers the cognitive tax.

Protect focus with boundaries: notifications off, do-not-disturb on, and a visible timer. Leave a visible sign for roommates during deep work.

Review daily in five minutes: capture new tasks, prune the list, and schedule one meaningful win for tomorrow.

title: Debugging JavaScript 101
content:
Start with a reproduction. Strip the code to the smallest failing example—if you can’t reproduce, you can’t reason.

Use the browser devtools: console, network panel, and breakpoints. Step through code to inspect state rather than guessing.

Check the data flow: inputs, transformations, outputs. Log at boundaries with clear prefixes so noise doesn’t drown the signal.

Write a test that fails, fix the bug, then watch the test pass. Leave the test in place to guard against regressions.
